articles.headline: At Talkspace, Start-Up Culture Collides With Mental Health Concerns
articles.snippet: The therapy-by-text company made burner phones available for fake reviews and doesn’t adequately respect client privacy, former employees say.
articles.abstract: The therapy-by-text company made burner phones available for fake reviews and doesn’t adequately respect client privacy, former employees say.
articles.lead_paragraph: In 2016, Ricardo Lori was an avid user of Talkspace — an app that lets people text and chat with a licensed therapist throughout the day. A part-time actor in New York City, Mr. Lori struggled with depression and anxiety, and he credited the app with helping him get out of an abusive relationship. He was a believer in Talkspace’s stated mission to make “therapy available and affordable for all,” and when the start-up offered him a job in its customer support department, Mr. Lori was ecstatic.
articles.byline: By Kashmir Hill and Aaron Krolik

articles.headline: Is TikTok More of a Parenting Problem Than a Security Threat?
articles.snippet: Even as the White House moves against the Chinese social media app, the intelligence agencies do not see it as a major issue along the lines of Huawei.
articles.abstract: Even as the White House moves against the Chinese social media app, the intelligence agencies do not see it as a major issue along the lines of Huawei.
articles.lead_paragraph: TikTok has long presented a parenting problem, as millions of Americans raising preteens and teenagers distracted by its viral videos can attest. But when the C.I.A. was asked recently to assess whether it was also a national security problem, the answer that came back was highly equivocal.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Russia Continues Interfering in Election to Try to Help Trump, U.S. Intelligence Says
articles.snippet: But a new assessment says China would prefer to see the president defeated, though it is not clear Beijing is doing much to meddle in the 2020 campaign to help Joseph R. Biden Jr.
articles.abstract: But a new assessment says China would prefer to see the president defeated, though it is not clear Beijing is doing much to meddle in the 2020 campaign to help Joseph R. Biden Jr.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Russia is using a range of techniques to denigrate Joseph R. Biden Jr., American intelligence officials said Friday in their first public assessment that Moscow continues to try to interfere in the 2020 campaign to help President Trump.
articles.byline: By Julian E. Barnes

articles.headline: Trump’s Orders on WeChat and TikTok Are Uncertain. That May Be the Point.
articles.snippet: The restrictions on the two Chinese-owned apps followed a familiar model for other policy announcements on China from the Trump administration.
articles.abstract: The restrictions on the two Chinese-owned apps followed a familiar model for other policy announcements on China from the Trump administration.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s sudden decision late Thursday to restrict two popular Chinese social media services from the United States has created confusion about how broad the bans on doing business with China could ultimately be.
articles.byline: By Ana Swanson

articles.headline: Millions of Evictions Are a Sharper Threat as Government Support Ends
articles.snippet: Without more federal aid for workers, experts are expecting the largest disruption to the housing market since the Depression.
articles.abstract: Without more federal aid for workers, experts are expecting the largest disruption to the housing market since the Depression.
articles.lead_paragraph: For the 108 million people who live in a rental home or apartment, Aug. 1 was a grim milestone. It marked the first time rent was due after much of the nation’s economic response to the coronavirus had expired.
articles.byline: By Conor Dougherty

articles.headline: Job Growth Slowed in July, Signaling a Loss of Economic Momentum
articles.snippet: The ranks of the employed grew by 1.8 million, a drop from the pace of the previous two months, as renewed business closings hampered the recovery.
articles.abstract: The ranks of the employed grew by 1.8 million, a drop from the pace of the previous two months, as renewed business closings hampered the recovery.
articles.lead_paragraph: The American economy slowed in July as the pace of hiring eased from the robust rate of the previous two months, a victim of waning momentum and the resurgence of the coronavirus in many parts of the country.
articles.byline: By Nelson D. Schwartz and Gillian Friedman

articles.headline: As Lebanon Reels, Long-Awaited Hariri Assassination Verdicts Loom
articles.snippet: A U.N.-backed court will soon pronounce verdicts in a 15-year-old bombing in Beirut that roiled the Middle East. But critics say the court’s protracted deliberations and huge expense have undermined its original purpose.
articles.abstract: A U.N.-backed court will soon pronounce verdicts in a 15-year-old bombing in Beirut that roiled the Middle East. But critics say the court’s protracted deliberations and huge expense have undermined its original purpose.
articles.lead_paragraph: The blast ripped off balconies along the Mediterranean, smashed windows blocks away and echoed across Beirut, leaving a city shattered by the immeasurable loss.
articles.byline: By Marlise Simons and Vivian Yee

articles.headline: When Covid-19 Hit, Many Elderly Were Left to Die
articles.snippet: Warnings had piled up for years that nursing homes were vulnerable. The pandemic sent them to the back of the line for equipment and care.
articles.abstract: Warnings had piled up for years that nursing homes were vulnerable. The pandemic sent them to the back of the line for equipment and care.
articles.lead_paragraph: BRUSSELS — Shirley Doyen was exhausted. The Christalain nursing home, which she ran with her brother in an affluent neighborhood in Brussels, was buckling from Covid-19. Eight residents had died in three weeks. Some staff members had only gowns and goggles from Halloween doctor costumes for protection.
articles.byline: By Matina Stevis-Gridneff, Matt Apuzzo, Monika Pronczuk and Mauricio Lima

articles.headline: Without $600 Weekly Benefit, Unemployed Face Bleak Choices
articles.snippet: A federal supplement to jobless pay was a lifeline for millions and for the economy. Its cutoff, even if temporary, may have lasting consequences.
articles.abstract: A federal supplement to jobless pay was a lifeline for millions and for the economy. Its cutoff, even if temporary, may have lasting consequences.
articles.lead_paragraph: When Latrish Oseko lost her job last spring, government aid helped prevent a crisis from becoming a catastrophe.
articles.byline: By Ben Casselman and Gillian Friedman

articles.headline: The Voting Will End Nov. 3. The Legal Battle Probably Won’t.
articles.snippet: As the two parties clash over how to conduct an election in a pandemic, President Trump’s litigiousness and unfounded claims of fraud have increased the likelihood of epic postelection court fights.
articles.abstract: As the two parties clash over how to conduct an election in a pandemic, President Trump’s litigiousness and unfounded claims of fraud have increased the likelihood of epic postelection court fights.
articles.lead_paragraph: The stormy once-in-a-lifetime Florida recount battle that polarized the nation in 2000 and left the Supreme Court to decide the presidency may soon look like a high school student council election compared with what could be coming after this November’s election.
articles.byline: By Peter Baker, Nick Corasaniti, Michael S. Schmidt and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: ‘Christianity Will Have Power’
articles.snippet: Donald Trump made a promise to white evangelical Christians, whose support can seem mystifying to the outside observer.
articles.abstract: Donald Trump made a promise to white evangelical Christians, whose support can seem mystifying to the outside observer.
articles.byline: By Elizabeth Dias

articles.headline: ‘Top Cop’ Kamala Harris’s Record of Policing the Police
articles.snippet: Senator Harris is speaking out amid the police reform movement. But how did she oversee police misconduct as a district attorney and attorney general?
articles.abstract: Senator Harris is speaking out amid the police reform movement. But how did she oversee police misconduct as a district attorney and attorney general?
articles.lead_paragraph: During this summer of tear gas and turmoil, Kamala Harris has not been quiet.
articles.byline: By Danny Hakim, Stephanie Saul and Richard A. Oppel Jr

articles.headline: This Contact Tracer Is Fighting Two Contagions: The Virus and Fear
articles.snippet: Convincing infected people to open up means helping them confront deeply held concerns about deportation or job loss.
articles.abstract: Convincing infected people to open up means helping them confront deeply held concerns about deportation or job loss.
articles.lead_paragraph: LOS ANGELES — Radhika Kumar goes to work every morning hoping to save lives. As a contact tracer for Los Angeles County, her job, at least on paper, entails phoning people who have tested positive for the coronavirus, along with others they may have exposed, and providing them with guidance on how to isolate so as not to infect others. If that sounds easy, it is not.
articles.byline: By Jo Becker

articles.headline: Boycotted. Criticized. But Fox News Leads the Pack in Prime Time.
articles.snippet: Led by Tucker Carlson and Sean Hannity, the channel’s pro-Trump lineup outranked every network from 8 to 11 p.m. in June and July.
articles.abstract: Led by Tucker Carlson and Sean Hannity, the channel’s pro-Trump lineup outranked every network from 8 to 11 p.m. in June and July.
articles.lead_paragraph: In one sense, this has been a difficult period for Fox News: a star anchor fired after being accused of sexual harassment, a lawsuit depicting a misogynist workplace, a top writer exposed as a racist internet troll, advertiser boycotts and outrage after Tucker Carlson called protesters “criminal mobs” and questioned the patriotism of a senator who lost her legs in Iraq.
articles.byline: By Michael M. Grynbaum

articles.headline: This Company Boasted to Trump About Its Covid-19 Vaccine. Experts Are Skeptical.
articles.snippet: Inovio, a Pennsylvania biotech company, has spent years claiming to be on the cusp of important vaccines. It has never brought one to market.
articles.abstract: Inovio, a Pennsylvania biotech company, has spent years claiming to be on the cusp of important vaccines. It has never brought one to market.
articles.lead_paragraph: As the deadly new virus spread globally, Inovio Pharmaceuticals, a small biotech company in Pennsylvania, rushed to develop a vaccine. After announcing promising early results, Inovio’s stock soared more than 1,000 percent. Riding the momentum, the company sold more shares to the public.
articles.byline: By David Gelles and Heather Murphy

articles.headline: Trump’s Orders on Coronavirus Relief Create Confusion
articles.snippet: Businesses and the unemployed faced uncertainty as administration officials defended the president’s directives and Democrats criticized them.
articles.abstract: Businesses and the unemployed faced uncertainty as administration officials defended the president’s directives and Democrats criticized them.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s attempt to circumvent Congress to provide coronavirus relief in the absence of a broad agreement resulted in confusion and uncertainty on Sunday for tens of millions of unemployed Americans and countless businesses seeking aid after critical benefits lapsed.
articles.byline: By Emily Cochrane, Alan Rappeport and Luke Broadwater

articles.headline: Trump’s Directives Were Supposed to Offer Relief. Most May Not.
articles.snippet: Because Congress controls federal spending, at least some of the measures will almost certainly be challenged in court. Or they may become moot if Congress reaches a deal.
articles.abstract: Because Congress controls federal spending, at least some of the measures will almost certainly be challenged in court. Or they may become moot if Congress reaches a deal.
articles.lead_paragraph: President Trump, in announcing his executive measures on Saturday, said he was bypassing Congress to deliver emergency pandemic aid to needy Americans. But his directives are rife with so much complexity and legal murkiness that they’re unlikely, in most cases, to bring fast relief — if any.
articles.byline: By Ron Lieber and Stacy Cowley

articles.headline: How Pro-Trump Forces Work the Refs in Silicon Valley
articles.snippet: The new referees in American politics are Facebook, Google and Twitter, and they would be wise to pay attention to lessons the old media tried to learn.
articles.abstract: The new referees in American politics are Facebook, Google and Twitter, and they would be wise to pay attention to lessons the old media tried to learn.
articles.lead_paragraph: One of the oddest moments during last month’s tech hearings on Capitol Hill came when a Florida congressman darkly hinted that Google was making it difficult for him to find a website he was looking for, The Gateway Pundit.
articles.byline: By Ben Smith

articles.headline: Hong Kong Arrests Jimmy Lai, Media Mogul, Under National Security Law
articles.snippet: The pro-democracy figure is the most high-profile person detained under the sweeping legislation imposed by Beijing. “It’s hard to believe this is Hong Kong,” said a journalist.
articles.abstract: The pro-democracy figure is the most high-profile person detained under the sweeping legislation imposed by Beijing. “It’s hard to believe this is Hong Kong,” said a journalist.
articles.lead_paragraph: HONG KONG — In a high-profile attack on free speech and dissent in Hong Kong, the police on Monday arrested Jimmy Lai, a prominent pro-democracy media tycoon, and raided the offices of his newspaper, demonstrating China’s resolve to silence the opposition and bring the city to heel.
articles.byline: By Austin Ramzy and Tiffany May

articles.headline: ‘I’d Rather Stay Home and Die’
articles.snippet: A fear of hospitals is leading many Mexicans to delay treatment for coronavirus until it is too late for doctors to help them.
articles.abstract: A fear of hospitals is leading many Mexicans to delay treatment for coronavirus until it is too late for doctors to help them.
articles.lead_paragraph: MEXICO CITY — A gray Suzuki stopped outside the General Hospital of Mexico and deposited a heaving Victor Bailón at the entrance. He had refused to come to the hospital for days, convinced that doctors were killing coronavirus patients. By the time he hobbled into the triage area and collapsed on the floor, it was too late.
articles.byline: By Natalie Kitroeff and Paulina Villegas

articles.headline: Big Tech Makes Inroads With the Biden Campaign
articles.snippet: While Joe Biden has criticized the largest tech companies, his campaign and transition teams have welcomed allies of Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple onto its staff and policy groups.
articles.abstract: While Joe Biden has criticized the largest tech companies, his campaign and transition teams have welcomed allies of Facebook, Google, Amazon and Apple onto its staff and policy groups.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Joseph R. Biden Jr. has been critical of Big Tech, admonishing Facebook for mishandling misinformation and saying internet companies should lose a central legal protection.
articles.byline: By David McCabe and Kenneth P. Vogel

articles.headline: Start-Ups Braced for the Worst. The Worst Never Came.
articles.snippet: The doomsday warnings about tech start-ups failing in the pandemic have not yielded the shakeout that many expected a few months ago.
articles.abstract: The doomsday warnings about tech start-ups failing in the pandemic have not yielded the shakeout that many expected a few months ago.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Getaround, a car sharing start-up, started the year by laying off 150 employees and scaling back some operations after it spent too much on a rapid expansion.
articles.byline: By Erin Griffith

articles.headline: Chicago Police Arrest More Than 100 People After Looting Batters Downtown
articles.snippet: The city briefly raised most of the bridges to the main shopping and business district. Mayor Lori Lightfoot condemned the crowd’s actions as “abject criminal behavior.”
articles.abstract: The city briefly raised most of the bridges to the main shopping and business district. Mayor Lori Lightfoot condemned the crowd’s actions as “abject criminal behavior.”
articles.lead_paragraph: CHICAGO — All summer, demonstrators have marched through Chicago to protest police misconduct. In many neighborhoods, gun violence has been unrelenting, soaring to levels not seen in decades. The coronavirus pandemic is resurging, now sickening hundreds of people each day.
articles.byline: By Julie Bosman, Christine Hauser and Johnny Diaz

articles.headline: McDonald’s Sues Former C.E.O., Accusing Him of Lying and Fraud
articles.snippet: The fast-food chain said Steve Easterbrook, who was fired last fall, concealed evidence during an investigation into his conduct.
articles.abstract: The fast-food chain said Steve Easterbrook, who was fired last fall, concealed evidence during an investigation into his conduct.
articles.lead_paragraph: Eight months had passed since McDonald’s fired its chief executive, Steve Easterbrook, for sexting with a subordinate. Mr. Easterbrook had apologized and walked away with tens of millions in compensation, and the fast-food chain had moved on under a new chief executive.
articles.byline: By David Enrich and Rachel Abrams

articles.headline: Delta Air Lines Bought an Oil Refinery. It Didn’t Go as Planned.
articles.snippet: Delta’s foray into oil refining illustrates some of the reasons the business was in trouble even before the pandemic.
articles.abstract: Delta’s foray into oil refining illustrates some of the reasons the business was in trouble even before the pandemic.
articles.lead_paragraph: Jet fuel is known as the Steady Eddie of the refinery business, a predictable profit maker that balances the seasonal gyrations of gasoline and diesel sales. But for airlines, it is a headache — a big and unpredictable expense that confounds managers.
articles.byline: By Clifford Krauss and Niraj Chokshi
